Spent several hours touring tall masted sailing vessels, learning history, viewing Cuban Missle crisis history in Russian Submarine tour, and touring the harbor!
Very Interesting, well spent few hours on the waterfront
This museum was included in our whale watching trip ticket, but I would have taken the tour anyway. This is a "don't miss" attraction for all ages. Go through many types of ships.
Give yourself enough time to read the informational displays

I found this very interesting--learning about how transportation by ship during the last couple centuries shaped our world today. We had planned to spend an hour, but stayed about 2 hours and still didn't get it all done.
A note to those who get motion-sick, as I am. I had no trouble going two floors below deck, as long as I work seabands on my wrists.
A note to those who are claustrophobic: I debated whether to go into 1960s-age Russian submarine. But I did and had no trouble. On deck are metal circles, that you can crawl through to understand what you will encounter below. And even though the circles may seem small, the rooms they lead to on the sub are not restrictive or small enough to have caused me any anxiety!
And you can retrace your steps if you feel unable to go on, anyway.
Show less

An unnaturally cold windy day in February made time on deck a little shorter and resulted in my skipping the (optional) harbor tour (optional), but there's good history here, and if you like ship models, well - it will be a treat. The Soviet sub along with its interesting historical role was great to see / learn, the older ships make you realize once again that things were once a lot more difficult - and uncomfortable - than they are now. Even the subs - could you manage it? There were not a lot of docents about, or maybe it was just to cold to ask and answer questions. This is well worth a stop, but if time is short and you must choose one - do Midway, you would not regret the decision.
Show less
Many ships, submarines and boats to visit

I have never been in a submarine so it was a thrill to be able to walk through two of them, one a Soviet sub and other an American. The contrasts between the subs were interesting. The Soviet sub had an interesting story, told in different parts of the boat, about how a similar sub came close to starting a war during the Cuban missile crisis. The giant sailing ship, "Star of India" has many interesting exhibits tracing its history as a passenger ship and then a cargo ship. It is clear that the museum is continually improving and refurbishing its collection.
Show less

This attraction showcases a marvelous variety of historic boats to tour, plus a submarine!! So much fun!! And it's right there on San Diego Bay, which is beautiful all on its own! For an extra $5 a person you can take a boat ride which is so much fun, and shows some highlights of the area from the water. So good!! The Maritime Museum is an excellent San Diego must see!!
Show less
A great place for history and adventure

We visited the Maritime Museum again on our visit in mid-February. We never tire of touring the ships and subs they have there. This was our first time taking a sailing cruise, however, and we took 2!
We were fortunate enough to be there for the Sweetheart Sail just before Valentines Day and were lucky enough to take it on the San Salvador! It was a real treat to be on a replica of a historic galleon. Captain Ray did a great job of giving us a tour of the harbor. It was a beautiful sunny day with low waves--perfect with delicious treats, champagne and a souvenir glass to remember the trip by.
The following day was also beautiful and calm, so we went out on the ocean on the America, with Captain Troy. We saw a pod of 5 whales, plus a few others; and a group of Pacific white-sided dolphins. There wasn't a lot of wind, but with an engine when needed we had a great excursion.
Show less
So much fun. We loved it as much as our grandkids!
Very affordable and the veterans that are onboard to offer so much more information are wonderful host!
I enjoyned rhis place a lot. This is a one of the best place to visit in couple of hours. You also come to know about the engineering used in boats and submarines.

My husband and I loved visiting this multiple ship and museum and harbor cruise Yes our entry fee covered all that We got to go on board the HMS Surprise the ship used in the filming of master and commander a Russian sub us sub see the museum and more
Great fun and very informative
Go
Show less

Nicely done floating maritime museum. We especially liked the Cold War - Cuban Missal Crisis theme presented onboard the Russian submarine. The Star of India was classic, while the Vietnam gunboat was a pleasant surprise. The details of the models on the ferry were also impressive. Well done!
Show less
There are four old ships and two submarines you can explore at the Maritime Museum. Lots of displays and several employees answering questions.
One of the best museums in San Diego!
This is an amazing museum. You can go inside two submarines, check out large wooden sailing craft and other ships. Lots of history and some very cool model ships as well. My favorite museum so far.
We visited the Maritime Museum on a Saturday in February with our 7 year old son. We loved all of the ships. This is totally worth the price of admission. It's a must-see in San Diego.
Some unique attractions, well worth a visit.

Its not often you get to be aboard an old steamer, russian submarine, the ship from Master and Commander and all together at this museum. It costs only a few dollars and for a few dollars more you can get to go out on a boat trip around the bay.
Show less

I have been to various maritime museums around the world, and San Diego, is on the top of the list. I am sure you could spend the whole day here. There are many ships to explore, the Star of India was very interesting, as was the Russian Sub from the Cuban Cold War. Just imagine living on one of these vessels from that time period, WOW
Show less

Another must see with several boats to roam through. The Star of India and the Russian sub were our favorites. It took us over 3 hours and could have stayed longer. I highly recommend getting the $5.00 45 min. harbor cruise add on. It's a real value on a small, solid, comfortable boat. All their volunteers are extremely knowledgeable.
Clean restrooms in various places. A good museum, and if you are lucky you will get to see and speak with a real miniature boatmaker who makes every teensy item from scratch. No kits. You can rent these as well for parties, wedding, or groups to take out of Dock. Be sure to go and spend the day. Open till 8 pm with all day in and out stamp.
Show less

What an interesting group of ships to tour. It is amazing how much work has gone into the restoration of these ships. Even the Russian sub. Very inexpensive to visit and a lot of great places to have lunch. A must see for all
Experience the time of the past.
Going through the ships, the subs was a lot of fun and at the same time a learning experience. I did the tours by my self and make sure you go online and use a coupon.
Great price for hrs of fun for adults and kids. Lots to see.

I can't say enough about this place. A must for locals as well as tourists. For $16 adult, cheaper for children and seniors. You get to go onto many ships and 2 submaries. Take your time as it's all self paced with places to sit and relax too. The Star of India sailing ship is the Star. Huge, multi levels to explore with a bathroom onboard. Another wooded masted ship next door too that was in movies including Pirates of the Carrebean with Johnny Depp. There's an old Russian Submarine with ladders and round doorways to maneuver through, about 5 doors like that. There's also an american sub witch is much easier to walk thru with full size doors. A great museum and other boats, including a pirate ship great for kids. All ages will enjoy this. Plan for at least 3 hrs to see everything at a leisurely pace. Longer for those that enjoy the maritime museum. Perfect location, paid metered parking, great views for a sunny day. You'll get your exercise too.
Show less

This museum consists of several docked vessels and a building with displays, a gift shop, and lecture halls / food area. Our group was there for a late evening social retreat as part of a conference.

The heart of this museum is clearly the ships:
HMS Surprise, a reproduction British sailing ship used in both Pirates of the Caribbean and Master and Commander movies. The top deck is period and the second deck has a number of information displays on the ship armament and seaboard life.

Star of India, a commercial sailing ship from the 1800s, used as transport for immigrants across the Pacific and for transporting fish from Alaska to California. Again, the deck is period and the lower decks have several informative displays.

A Soviet and an American submarine, neither of which I toured. The soviet vessel was noted as having several tight passages and the American vessel was closed for repairs.

The building holds several displays of equipment and models, mainly of military ships.

This museum is worth a couple of hours, and combined with the Midway, which is docked nearby but not part of the museum, would make a good visit while in San Diego.

As a social event location, I found it pleasant. The staff were attentive and the food was tended well and of nice variety. The range of spaces offered good opportunity for discussions. The spaces were well lighted and well maintained.
Show less
You Should Be Sure to Go

Pick a nice day and go to this Maritime Museum. The Star of India and the San Salvador are gorgeous ships. They were working on the Star of India, but we still had access to most of the areas. The displays are well done and informative. The Russian sub has a 'passageway' mock-up before you enter the ship. I suggest you try going through it before you enter to make sure you really can climb through easily. There are about four or five of them once you're on the sub itself.
